These two ledger history changesets are ready for +2 reviews:
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2559/>
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3159/>
Just to start clearing the stack a bit, I've broken some work into small changesets. These have been +2'd already, looking for a quorum:
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3191/2>
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3193/2>
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3195/2>
(I have merged 3191)

OK, <@U0KN2SSKE>, <@U0XQ35CDD>: I have reviewed and merged them 3 CRs. When you/we have more time, I’d appreciate us not using the extra “_” in file names. At the same time, these CRs were very well documented. Thank you.
<@U11MANG9G>: Thank you (and thank you). Interesting point on the "_". Is there a particular reason for this, or is it just a matter of preference?
As far as I can tell, there is no style guide for this (though I'm all in favor of adopting one), and there is no established pattern in the community.
Well, it’s a strange one. In Golang these _ are reserved for two things. YOUFILE_test.go are for tests...
Not really. <http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25161774/what-are-conventions-for-filenames-in-go>

attachments.title: What are conventions for filenames in Go?
attachments.text: I could find the conventions for naming packages in Go: no underscore between words, everything lowercase.Does this convention apply to the filenames too?Do you also put one struct in one file ...
attachments.fallback: What are conventions for filenames in Go?

text: and/or for platform specific implementations...
I know, I know, some Golang devs are breaking this rule in some places...
I object to the word "reserved" I guess. But I'll note that all of my mock files will eventually move to the `mocks` package in orderer, so this issue will resolve itself.
But in general, the idea is that the `packages` what matters (more than files. And indeed, using subdirectories help “componentize” these much better.

(Yes, that’s why I have prefixed with “Well, it’s a strange one” :wink:… it is not enforced everywhere, but I find it helpful to have more “self-contained” services that live side by side happily :wink:. Maybe it’s the holiday atmosphere, I don’t know ;-))
Ok, we’ve gotten two +2s at various times for:
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2559/>
<https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3159/>
Just need them merged now!
